facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 164 of 1952 arises from the judgment and decree dated 12th August 1949 of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 164 of 1952. Appeal from the Judgment and Decree dated the 12th August, 1949, of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay in Appeals Nos. 63 and 148 of 1947, from Original Decree, arising out of the Decree dated the 31st July, 1946, of the Court of the Civil Judge, Senior Division, Bijapur, at Bijapur in Special Civil- Suit No. 28 of 1945.

facts.text: The suit was instituted by the appellant in the Court of the Civil Judge Senior Division, Bijapur as Special Civil Suit No. 28 of 1945.

anchor.surface_text: VENKATARAMA AYYAR J.-This appeal arises out of a suit for partition instituted by the appellant in the Court of the Civil Judge Senior Division, Bijapur.

facts.text: Trial court decree dated 31st July 1946.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Decree dated the 12th August, 1949, of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay in Appeals Nos. 63 and 148 of 1947, from Original Decree, arising out of the Decree dated the 31st July, 1946, of the Court of the Civil Judge, Senior Division, Bijapur

facts.text: Krishnarao died in 1897 leaving behind widow Rukminibai, sixth defendant.

anchor.surface_text: Siddopant and Krishnarao were members of a joint undivided family. Krishnarao died in 1897 leaving behind a widow, Rukminibai, who is the sixth defendant in the suit.

facts.text: Siddopant died in 1899 leaving surviving son Gundo who died in 1901 leaving widow Lakshmibai, fifth defendant.

anchor.surface_text: Siddopant died in 1899 leaving him surviving his son, Gundo, who died in 1901 leaving behind a widow, Lakahmibai, who is the fifth defendant.

facts.text: On 16th December 1901, Lakshmibai adopted Devji who died on 6th May 1935 leaving three sons defendants 1 to 3 and widow Akkubai fourth defendant.

anchor.surface_text: On 16th December, 1901, Lakshmibai adopted Devji, who died on 6th May, 1935, leaving three sons, defendants Nos. 1 to 3, and a widow, Akkubai, the fourth defendant.

facts.text: On 26th April 1944, Rukminibai adopted the plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: On 26th April, 1944, Rukminibai adopted the plaintiff, and on 29th June, 1944, he instituted the present suit for partition claiming a half share in the family properties.

facts.text: Plaintiff instituted suit for partition on 29th June 1944 claiming half share in family properties.

anchor.surface_text: On 26th April, 1944, Rukminibai adopted the plaintiff, and on 29th June, 1944, he instituted the present suit for partition claiming a half share in the family properties.

facts.text: Watan lands: Siddopant and Krishnarao entitled to whole of S. No. 138 and half share in 133 and 136 Ukamnal, half in 163,164,168 Katakanhalli.

anchor.surface_text: Siddopant and Krishnarao represented one branch of a Kulkarni family and were entitled for their share of the Watan lands, to the whole of S. No. 138 and a half share in Nos. 133 and 136 in the village of Ukamnal and a half share in S. Nos. 163, 164 and 168 in the village of Katakanhalli.

facts.text: Swamirao other branch entitled to whole S.No.137 and half in 133,136 Ukamnal, half 163,164,168 Katakanhalli.

anchor.surface_text: The other branch was represented by Swamirao, who was entitled for his half share of the Watan lands, to the whole of S. No. 137 and to a half share in S.Nos. 133 and 136 in the village of Ukamnal and to a half share in S. Nos. 163, 164 and 168 in the village of Katakanhalli.

facts.text: Swamirao died about 1903 issueless, his widow died shortly after, properties devolved on Devji as nearest agnate, listed in Schedule C.

anchor.surface_text: Swainirao died about 1903 issueless, and on the death of his widow shortly thereafter, his properties devolved on Devji as his nearest agnate, and they are set out in Schedule C to the plaint.

facts.text: Defendants denied validity of plaintiff's adoption.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants denied the truth and validity of the plaintiffs adoption.

facts.text: Both lower courts held plaintiff's adoption true and valid, no longer disputed.

anchor.surface_text: Both the Courts below have held that the adoption of the plaintiff is true and valid, and that question is numberlonger in dispute before us.

facts.text: Lower courts held purchases by Siddopant and houses by him and Devji were self-acquisitions.

anchor.surface_text: They have also held that the purchases made by Siddopant and the houses built by him were his self-acquisitions, as was also the house built by Devji.

facts.text: Trial court held plaintiff entitled to half share in S.Nos. 639 and 640 as ancestral, but High Court reversed.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court held that the plaintiff was entitled to a half share in S. Nos. 639 and 640 in Schedule A on the ground that they belonged to the family as ancestral properties but the High Court held that that had number been established.

facts.text: High Court held Schedule C properties belong exclusively to Devji following Jivaji Annaji v. Hanmant Ramchandra.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the properties set out in Schedule C, while the trial Court decided that the appellant was entitled to them exclusively under the decision of the Privy Council in Anant Bhikappa Patil Minor v. Shankar Ramchandra Patil1 , the High Court held following a Full Bench decision of that Court in Jivaji Annaji v. Hanmant Ramchandra2 , that they belonged exclusively to Devji

facts.text: Both courts agreed no blending of properties with joint family properties.

anchor.surface_text: Both the Courts a reed in negativing the companytention of the plaintiff that there had been a blending of these properties with the joint family properties.

facts.text: High Court granted decree for partition of admitted Watan lands, dismissed rest.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the High Court granted a decree in favour of the plaintiff for partition of the admitted Watan ,lands, and otherwise dismissed the suit.

facts.text: Ancestral Watan lands about 56 acres, annual assessment Rs.49.

anchor.surface_text: On the question of the nucleus, the only properties which were proved to belong to the joint family were the Watan lands of the extent of about 56 acres, bearing an annual assessment of Rs. 49.

facts.text: Siddopant purchased house on 21st May 1871 for Rs.200 under Ex.D-36.

anchor.surface_text: Coming next to the acquisitions, on 21st May, 1871, Siddopant purchased under Exhibit D-36 a house for Rs.200 from his mother-in-law.

facts.text: Siddopant purchased S.No.23 Ukamnal on 11th May 1885 for Rs.475 under Ex.D-61.

anchor.surface_text: On 11th May,1885, he purchased under Exhibit D-61 S. No. 23 Ukamnal village for a sum of Rs. 475.

facts.text: Siddopant purchased S.Nos.2025 and 2140 on 23rd July 1890 for Rs.2400 under Ex.D-64.

anchor.surface_text: On 23rd July, 1890, he purchased under Exhibit D- 64 lands bearing S. Nos. 2025 and 2140 for Rs. 2,400. In this suit, we are companycerned only with S. No. 2025.

facts.text: Siddopant constructed two houses costing Rs.20,000-25,000.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from these purchases, he companystructed two houses, one on S. Nos. 639, 640 and 641, and another on S.Nos. 634 and 635. D.Ws. 2 and 3 have deposed that these companystructions would have companyt between Rs. 20,000 and Rs. 25,000

facts.text: Devji built house after 1901 on S.Nos.642,644,645 costing Rs.2000-4000.

anchor.surface_text: After 1901, Devji built a house on S. Nos. 642, 644 and 645 at a companyt estimated between Rs. 2,000 and 4,000.

facts.text: Siddopant was Tahsildar in Hyderabad for 40 years, retired on pension.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence is that Siddopant was a Tahsildar in the State of Hyderabad, and was in service for a period of 40 years before he retired on pension.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds house sites S.Nos. 634,635; 639,640,641; 642,644,645 are ancestral, plaintiff entitled to half value.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, it must be held that the plots, S. Nos. 634 and 635, S. Nos. 639, 640 and 641 and S. Nos. 642, 644 and 645 are ancestral properties, and that the plaintiff is entitled to a half share therein.

facts.text: Supreme Court rejects plaintiff's claim to Schedule C properties, no relation back for collateral inheritance.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the High Court in respect of C, Schedule properties must therefore be affirmed.

facts.text: No blending of C Schedule properties, courts found against plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: This is a question of fact on which the Courts below have companycurrently found against the appellant, and there are numbergrounds for differing from them.

facts.text: S.No.622 purchased by Devji at government auction in 1909.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from Exhibit D-43 that this was purchased by Devji at a Government auction in the year 1909.

facts.text: Plaintiff claims half share in properties as representing Krishnarao.

anchor.surface_text: he instituted the present suit for partition claiming a half share in the family properties.

The law was thus stated in that case The Hindu law upon this aspect of the case is well settled. Proof of the existence of a joint family does not lead to the presumption that property held by any member of the family is joint, and the burden rests upon anyone asserting that any item of property was joint to establish the fact. But where it is established that the family possessed some joint property which from its nature and relative value may have formed the nucleus from which the property in question may

concepts.interpretation: Burden lies on party claiming property as joint family property; existence of nucleus with sufficient income shifts burden to prove self-acquisition without joint aid. Here, inadequate nucleus income means no shift, plaintiff fails initial burden.

concepts.interpretation: House sites without title deeds presumed ancestral if long possession; burden on self-acquisition claim. Applied to grant plaintiff half share in specific plots.

anchor.surface_text: the ground on which an adopted son is held entitled to take in defeasance of the rights acquired prior to his adoption is that in the eye of law his adoption relates back, by a legal fiction, to the date of the death of his adoptive father

concepts.interpretation: Legal fiction of relation back to adoptive father's death for continuity of line; applies to adoptive father's estate (joint or separate), including divestment of prior heirs, but not to collaterals' estates where inheritance vested earlier.
concepts.unlisted_description: Retrospective effect of adoption to date of adoptive father's death

concepts.interpretation: Heavy burden on claimant to prove intention to abandon separate character; concurrent findings against plaintiff upheld.

anchor.surface_text: inheritance can never be in abeyance, and that once it devolves on a person who is the nearest heir under the law, it is thereafter not liable to be divested.

concepts.interpretation: Inheritance vests immediately on death; not held in abeyance for potential adopted son unless to adoptive father. No divestment for collaterals.

anchor.surface_text: the coparcenary must be held to subsist so long as there was in existence a widow of a coparcener capable of bringing a son into existence by adoption

concepts.interpretation: Coparcenary continues via widow's adoption power; but limited, rejected extension per Anant Bhikappa for collaterals.

issues.text: whether the finding of the Courts below that the properties purchased by Siddopant and the houses constructed by him and Devji were self-acquisitions, is erroneous, firstly because the burden was wrongly cast on the plaintiff of proving that they were made with the aid of joint family funds

anchor.surface_text: The first contention that has been urged on behalf of the appellant is that the finding of the Courts below that the properties purchased by Siddopant and the houses constructed by him and Devji were self-acquisitions, is erroneous, firstly because the burden was wrongly cast on the plaintiff of proving that they were made with the aid of joint family funds, and secondly because certain documents which had been tendered in evidence by the plaintiff had been wrongly rejected as inadmissible.

issues.text: whether certain documents which were tendered in evidence had been wrongly rejected by the Courts below

anchor.surface_text: It was, next contended that certain documents which were tendered in evidence had been wrongly rejected by the Courts below, and that the finding of self-acquisition reached without reference to those documents should not be accepted.

issues.text: whether certain plots mentioned in Schedule A in which the plaintiff claims a half share... are ancestral properties

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the Watan lands which are admittedly ancestral, and apart from the purchases made under Exhibits. D-36, D- 61 and D-64 and the houses which we have held to be self- acquisitions, there are certain plots mentioned in Schedule A in which the plaintiff claims a half share. These are the sites on which the houses have been constructed. The contention of the plaintiff is that they are ancestral properties.

issues.text: The point for determination now is whether this doctrine of relation back can be applied when the claim made by the adopted son relates not to the estate of his adoptive father but of a collateral.

anchor.surface_text: The point for determination now is whether this doctrine of relation back can be applied when the claim made by the adopted son relates not to the estate of his adoptive father but of a collateral. The theory on which this doctrine is based is that there should be no hiatus in, the continuity of the line of the adoptive father.

issues.text: whether the defendants had blended C Schedule properties along with the admitted ancestral properties so as to impress them with the character of joint family properties

arguments.claim: The properties purchased by Siddopant and the houses constructed by him and Devji were made with the aid of joint family funds from the ancestral Watan lands nucleus, so burden shifts to defendants to prove self-acquisition

anchor.surface_text: On the first question, the argument of the appellant is that as the family admittedly possessed income-producing nucleus in the ancestral Watan lands of the extent of 56 acres, it must be presumed that the acquisitions standing in the name of Siddopant were made with the aid of joint family funds, that the burden lay on the defendants who claimed that they were self-acquisitions to establish that they were made without the aid of joint family funds, that the evidence adduced by them fell far short of it, and that the presumption in favour of the plaintiff stood unrebutted.

holdings.text: The properties purchased by Siddopant and the houses constructed by him and Devji were self-acquisitions as the plaintiff failed to discharge the initial burden of proving adequate joint family nucleus and defendants discharged any shifted burden.

anchor.surface_text: The law was thus stated in that case The Hindu law upon this aspect of the case is well settled. Proof of the existence of a joint family does not lead to the presumption that property held by any member of the family is joint, and the burden rests upon anyone asserting that any item of property was joint to establish the fact. But where it is established that the family possessed some joint property which from its nature and relative value may have formed the nucleus from which the property in question may

holdings.reasoning_summary: Watan lands nucleus inadequate (annual assessment Rs.49, insufficient even for maintenance); Siddopant had independent Tahsildar salary/pension over 40 years; acquisitions total ~Rs.30,000; applies Appalaswami v. Suryanarayanamurti; concurrent lower findings upheld.

holdings.text: Maintenance judgments admissible under S.13 Evidence Act as assertions of joint family properties but properly rejected under Order XIII Rule 2 CPC for late production without grounds to reopen trial.

anchor.surface_text: these judgments are admissible under section 13 of the Evidence Act as assertions of Rukminibai that the properties in dispute belonged to the joint family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relevant to extent of joint properties for maintenance quantum; produced after evidence closed, defendants opposed reopening; trial court order upheld.

holdings.text: House sites S.Nos. 634-635, 639-641, 642/644/645 are ancestral properties without title deeds evidenced by long possession and sanads confirming prior occupation; plaintiff entitled to half value as superstructure exists.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, it must be held that the plots, S. Nos. 634 and 635, S. Nos. 639, 640 and 641 and S. Nos. 642, 644 and 645 are ancestral properties, and that the plaintiff is entitled to a half share therein.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presumption of ancestral where no title deed but immemorial family possession; sanads (D-45 to D-51) recognize prior occupation; excludes S.622 (D-43 govt auction 1909), S.643 (temple); reverses High Court requiring acquisition proof.

holdings.text: Relation back doctrine of adoption applies only to adoptive father's estate for line continuity, not to collateral's inherited properties where inheritance vests immediately without abeyance; adopted son cannot divest vested collateral inheritance; Anant Bhikappa overruled insofar.

anchor.surface_text: the ground on which an adopted son is held entitled to take in defeasance of the rights acquired prior to his adoption is that in the eye of law his adoption relates back, by a legal fiction, to the date of the death of his adoptive father

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fiction limited to adoptive father's line (joint or separate); collateral descent differs; immediate vesting prevents divestment (Mulla, Bhubaneswari); inconvenient for long-term alienees without necessity binding; distinguishes joint family cases.

holdings.text: No blending of Schedule C properties with joint family properties.

anchor.surface_text: This is a question of fact on which the Courts below have concurrently found against the appellant, and there are no grounds for differing from them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Heavy burden on plaintiff to prove intent to abandon separate character; concurrent lower court findings of fact upheld, no interference grounds.

outcome.relief_summary: Decree of lower court (High Court) modified to grant plaintiff decree for half the value of ancestral house sites/plots S. Nos. 634 & 635, 639, 640 & 641, 642, 644 & 645. Other claims (self-acquisitions, C Schedule properties, blending) rejected. Partition of Watan lands affirmed.
directions: granting the plaintiff a decree for half the value of the plots, S. Nos. 634 and 635, S. Nos. 639, 640 and 641 and S. Nos. 642, 644 and 645 as on the date of the suit

anchor.surface_text: The law was thus stated in that case The Hindu law upon this aspect of the case is well settled. Proof of the existence of a joint family does not lead to the presumption that property held by any member of the family is joint, and the burden rests upon anyone asserting that any item of property was joint to establish the fact. But where it is established that the family possessed some joint property which from its nature and relative value may have formed the nucleus from which the property in question may
